Package neureka.backend.api.algorithms

Class AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C extends Algorithm<C>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • neureka.backend.api.algorithms.AbstractBaseAlgorithm<C>
      • neureka.backend.api.algorithms.AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C>
  • Type Parameters:
    C - The final type extending this class.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Algorithm<C>, ADAgentSupplier, BackwardADPredicate, ExecutionDispatcher, ExecutionPreparation, ForwardADPredicate, SuitabilityPredicate
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Activation, Broadcast, Convolution, FunAlgorithm, Operator, ScalarActivation, ScalarBroadcast, Scalarization
    public abstract class AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C extends Algorithm<C>>
extends AbstractBaseAlgorithm<C>
    This is the base class for implementations of the Algorithm interface. The class implements a basic component system, as is implicitly expected by said interface. Additionally, it contains useful methods used to process passed arguments of ExecutionCall as well as an implementation of the Algorithm interface which allows its methods to be implemented in a functional programming style, meaning that instances of concrete implementations extending this abstract class have setters for lambdas representing the Algorithm methods. It is being used by the standard backend of Neureka as abstract base class for various algorithms. Conceptually an implementation of the Algorithm interface represents "a sub-kind of operation" for an instance of an implementation of the Operation interface.
    The "+" operator for example has different Algorithm instances tailored to specific requirements originating from different ExecutionCall instances with unique arguments. Tsr instances within an execution call having the same shape would cause the Operation instance to chose an Algorithm instance which is responsible for performing elementwise operations, whereas otherwise the Broadcast algorithm might be called to perform the operation.

    • Method Detail

      • isSuitableFor

        public final float isSuitableFor​(ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call)
        The SuitabilityPredicate checks if a given instance of an ExecutionCall is suitable to be executed in ImplementationFor residing in this Algorithm as components. It can be implemented as s simple lambda.
        Parameters:
        call - The ExecutionCall whose suitability for execution on this Algorithm ought to be determined.
        Returns:
        The suitability degree expressed by a float value between 0 and 1, where 0 means not suitable and 1 means suitable.

      • canPerformForwardADFor

        public final boolean canPerformForwardADFor​(ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call)
        The ForwardADPredicate lambda implemented by this method checks if forward mode auto differentiation can be performed for a given ExecutionCall. The analyzer returns a boolean truth value.
        Parameters:
        call - The ExecutionCall call for which the forward mode auto differentiation suitability ought to be checked.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if forward mode auto differentiation can be performed.

      • canPerformBackwardADFor

        public final boolean canPerformBackwardADFor​(ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call)
        A BackwardADPredicate lambda checks if backward mode auto differentiation (also known as back-propagation) can be performed for a given ExecutionCall. The analyzer returns a boolean truth value.
        Parameters:
        call - The ExecutionCall call for which the backward mode auto differentiation suitability ought to be checked.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if backward mode auto differentiation can be performed.

      • supplyADAgentFor

        public final ADAgent supplyADAgentFor​(Function function,
                                      ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call,
                                      boolean forward)
        This method returns a new instance of the ADAgent class responsible for performing automatic differentiation both for forward and backward mode differentiation.
        Therefore an ADAgent exposes 2 different procedures.
        One is the forward mode differentiation, and the other one
        is the backward mode differentiation which is more commonly known as back-propagation...
        Besides that it may also contain context information used
        to perform said procedures.
        Parameters:
        function - The function from where the request for auto differentiation originates.
        call - The execution call of the current execution which requires auto differentiation support.
        forward - The truth value determining the type of differentiation that should be performed.
        Returns:
        The resulting ADAgent.

      • dispatch

        public final Tsr<?> dispatch​(FunctionNode caller,
                             ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call)
        This method implements the ExecutionDispatcher lambda which is the final execution procedure responsible for electing an ImplementationFor the chosen Device in a given ExecutionCall. However, the ExecutionDispatcher does not have to select a device specific implementation. It can also occupy the rest of the execution without any other steps being taken. For example, a ImplementationFor or a RecursiveExecutor would not be used if not explicitly called. Bypassing other procedures is useful for full control and of course to implement unorthodox types of operations like the Reshape operation which is very different from classical operations. Although the ExecutionCall passed to implementations of this will contain a fairly suitable Device assigned to a given Algorithm, one can simply ignore it and find a custom one which fits the contents of the given ExecutionCall instance better.
        Parameters:
        caller - The FunctionNode from which this request for execution emerged.
        call - The ExecutionCall whose contents ought to be executed.
        Returns:
        The result of the execution.

      • prepare

        public final ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> prepare​(ExecutionCall<? extends Device<?>> call)
        Preparing refers to instantiating output tensors for the provided ExecutionCall.
        Parameters:
        call - The execution call which needs to be prepared for execution.
        Returns:
        The prepared ExecutionCall instance.

      • buildFunAlgorithm

        public final C buildFunAlgorithm()
        Returns:
        A new concrete implementation of the AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm which is fully built and ready to be used as an Operation component.

      • setIsSuitableFor

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setIsSuitableFor​(SuitabilityPredicate isSuitableFor)
        The SuitabilityPredicate received by this method checks if a given instance of an ExecutionCall is suitable to be executed in ImplementationFor instances residing in this Algorithm as components. The lambda will be called by the isSuitableFor(ExecutionCall) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        isSuitableFor - The suitability predicate which determines if the algorithm is suitable or not.
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.

      • setCanPerformForwardADFor

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setCanPerformForwardADFor​(ForwardADPredicate canPerformForwardADFor)
        A ForwardADPredicate lambda checks if this Algorithm can perform forward AD for a given ExecutionCall. The lambda will be called by the canPerformForwardADFor(ExecutionCall) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        canPerformForwardADFor - The lambda which evaluates if a provided ExecutionCall can be forward propagated.
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.

      • setCanPerformBackwardADFor

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setCanPerformBackwardADFor​(BackwardADPredicate canPerformBackwardADFor)
        A BackwardADPredicate lambda checks if this Algorithm can perform backward AD for a given ExecutionCall. The lambda will be called by the canPerformBackwardADFor(ExecutionCall) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        canPerformBackwardADFor - A predicate lambda which determines if this algorithm can perform backward AD for a given execution call.
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.

      • setSupplyADAgentFor

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setSupplyADAgentFor​(ADAgentSupplier supplyADAgentFor)
        This method receives a ADAgentSupplier which will supply ADAgent instances which can perform backward and forward auto differentiation. The lambda will be called by the supplyADAgentFor(Function, ExecutionCall, boolean) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        supplyADAgentFor - A supplier for an ADAgent containing implementation details for autograd.
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.

      • setExecutionDispatcher

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setExecutionDispatcher​(ExecutionDispatcher handleInsteadOfDevice)
        The ExecutionDispatcher lambda is the most important procedure within an Algorithm, which is responsible for electing an ImplementationFor the chosen Device in a given ExecutionCall passed to the ExecutionDispatcher. However, the ExecutionDispatcher does not have to select a device specific implementation. It can also occupy the rest of the execution without any other steps being taken. For example, a ImplementationFor or a RecursiveExecutor would not be used if not explicitly called. Bypassing other procedures is useful for full control and of course to implement unorthodox types of operations like the Reshape operation which is very different from classical operations. Although the ExecutionCall passed to implementations of this will contain a fairly suitable Device assigned to a given Algorithm, one can simply ignore it and find a custom one which fits the contents of the given ExecutionCall instance better. The lambda passed to this will be called by the dispatch(FunctionNode, ExecutionCall) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        handleInsteadOfDevice - The ExecutionDispatcher which is the main entrypoint for execution.
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.

      • setCallPreparation

        public final AbstractFunctionalAlgorithm<C> setCallPreparation​(ExecutionPreparation instantiateNewTensorsForExecutionIn)
        An Algorithm will typically produce a result when executing an ExecutionCall. This result must be created somehow. A ExecutionPreparation implementation instance will do just that... Often times the first entry in the array of tensors stored inside the call will be null to serve as a position for the output to be placed at. The creation of this output tensor is of course highly dependent on the type of operation and algorithm that is currently being used. Element-wise operations for example will require the creation of an output tensor with the shape of the provided input tensors, whereas the execution of a linear operation like for example a broadcast operation will require a very different approach... The lambda passed to this will be called by the prepare(ExecutionCall) method by any given Operation instances this algorithm belongs to.
        Parameters:
        instantiateNewTensorsForExecutionIn - A lambda which prepares the provided execution call (usually output instantiation).
        Returns:
        This very instance to enable method chaining.
